div.p: RICAUT or Rycaut (Sir Paul), an eminent Engliſh traveller, of the time of whoſe birth we find no account ; but in 166r, he was appointed ſecretary to the earl of Winchelſea, who was ſent ambaſſador extraordinary to the Ottoman Porte. During his continuance in that ſtation, he wrote, “ The preſent State of the Ottoman Empire, in three books, containing the maxims of the Turkiſh policy, their religion, and military diſcipline,” London, folio, 1670. He afterwards reſided 1 x years as conſnl at Smyrna, where, at the command of Charles II. he compoſed “ The preſent ſtate of the Greek and Armenian Churches, anno Cl)r∙ifti 1678.” On his return, Lord Clarendon being appointed lord-lieutenant of Ireland, made him his principal ſecretary for Leinſter and Connaught : king James II. knighted him ; and made him one of the privy council in Ireland, and judge of the court of admiralty ; all which he held to the Revolution. He was employed by King William as reſident at the Hanſe-towns in Lower Saxony, where he continued for ten years ; but being worn out with age and infirmities, he obtained leave to return in 1700, and died the fame year. Ricaut continued “ Knolles’s Hiſtory of the Turks, and Platina’s Lives of the Popes beſides which, there are ſome other productions under his name.
